text: hi everyone what's up anthony boptano
here the internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for
a review of the new self-titled
twin shadow album this is a brand new lp
from singer multi-instrumentalist
producer and
songwriter mr george lewis jr aka twin
shadow
this is his fifth full-length record
it's been released independently through
his
shari sheree record label now if you are
familiar with twin shadow you might know
that he
is one of the uh bigger indie buzzes of
the 2010s
he went on from his splash of a debut to
put out one record after another where
he indulged in some pretty anthemic
synth pop years before
uh this current trend of of 80 stuff
uh topping the charts at the moment i
highly recommend you check those
projects out even if i'm not crazy about
a lot of them myself
but what did grab my attention was the
change of pace
george seemed to be offering on some of
the singles leading up to the release of
this
new record johnny and johnny get closer
lone star all songs that pointed toward
a record that
could be summery psychedelic as well as
a slightly tropical with
touches of dub and ska and essentially
with a twin shadow here we got that
and more as this record is easily
george's most
instrumentally vibrant project in a long
time if not
ever the opening track alone is an
impressive display of
arrangement around a pretty
straightforward acoustic ballad
which sounds like it's set in the desert
george sings on this one with a crisp
delay against some easy going drums
analog synth leads some massive chorus
harmonies too
the track's an instant sing-along for me
not much else on the lp sounds just like
this song but that's kind of the fun of
twin
shadow here it seems like george is uh
just really
into the idea of just hopping into
whatever sound and vibe that
inspires him or that he just like really
enjoys personally
sugarcane is some instrumentally
detailed psychedelic pop that is
snappy easy to listen to but packed with
some
finite nuances for anybody who wants to
dig in a little deeper
there are maybe a few moments on this
one where the effects were laid on
a little too heavy especially on the
chorus vocals but it's still an example
of some strong songwriting but the
biggest
smashes on the front end of this thing
come when johnny johnny enters the room
which i mentioned earlier this track is
a feel-good groovy trippy call
back to dub and ska that is just
incredible from end to end
the wavy delays the sax solo the hook
some of the synth leads the build up on
the bridge there's not a section of this
track where george is not packing it
with heat in terms of writing production
and performance he
really did not need to go this hard then
get closer i think is another pop smash
waiting for its moment the tense and
intimate verses on this one build up
subtly as george
deals in themes of communication arguing
love
distance then the explosive hook on this
thing just
hits heavy with strings more guitar
horns groovy bass it sounds like a
paul simon nod if there ever was one and
it's a well
done one then is there any love is a
radical funk track
that reflects pretty boldly on the
police brutality authoritarianism as
well as protests
of the last year or so the groove and
instrumental layers are amazing the tone
george takes with the lyrics is perfect
he puts things pretty clearly as he says
stop in your cruisers
stop with your rage the more you abuse
us the more we arrange
then gated windows is a bit of a lyrical
meditation on george's
home country of the dominican republic
not a favorite here for me but i still
do admire the track for being
maybe the most unique sounding on the
entire lp the song is so oddly sung
and harmonized against these gurgling
bass lines disorienting effects
just very weird synthesizers and of
course more dub inspired delays
there's a sour demeanor to it but george
still leaves us
with a lot to take in it's slightly
off-putting but
it's by no means boring modern man is
then a spotlit ballad that
i really appreciate for being as
skeletal as
it is but the pacing of the song i think
could use some work
for something this dramatic it shouldn't
sound so in a rush
but then lone star which was another
favorite of mine in the track list
is a scott anthem about george's lone
wolf status essentially
being burned too many times learning
from that the instrumental on this one
is impeccable too but what really takes
me here is how
authoritative confident and just
righteous and free
george feels as he's delivering these
lyrics i also see some
similar themes of feeling exploited and
taken advantage of on the following
brown sugar too but
obviously a different angle coming
through on that track then the closing
track i want to be here
shotgun is a moment of existential
affirmation george singing about
him wanting to be here doing what he's
doing existing
thriving wanting to be in this ride of
life and setting those feelings to
uplifting vocal harmonies and horns it's
a feel-good finish to a record that
ultimately sounds like
an artist who is seasoned at this point
and
successfully turning the first page into
the second act of his career which given
the quality of this record i think he's
giving us a
lot to enjoy now but also a lot to look
forward to in terms of
uh risk taking ambition and just maybe
something uh new and exciting coming
down the pipe
i'm feeling a strong seven to a light
eight on
this one tran position have you given
this album a listen did you love it did
you hate it
why what do you think i should review
next and uh
yeah yeah you're the best subscribe uh
freaking hit that bell so you get
notifications over here next to my head
it's another one that you can check out
i'll see you in the next one anthony
fantano
twin shadow twin shadow forever
